The copper galloping horse in the Eatern Han Dynasty is the bronze sculpture known as the Galloping Horse Treading on a Flying Swallow

its head raised and tilted, flared nostrils and wide, bulging eyes

It consists primarily of wooden chains, water, and scrapers.
The wooden chains resemble keels.
When lifting water, they are typically placed near the riverbank, with the water trough and scrapers extending underwater.
Using a sprocket drive principle, powered by human (or animal) power, the wooden chains rotate repeatedly.
The scrapers attached to the chains then lift the river water to the shore for irrigation.
Keel Waterwheel
The Sword of Goujian is a bronze sword renowned for its unusual sharpness, intricate design of black rhombuc etchings
The sword of Goujian is 55.6 centimetres (21.9 in) in length, including an 8.4 centimetres (3.3 in) hilt; the blade is 4.6 centimetres (1.8 in) wide at its base
The sword has a black hilt
In addition to the repeating dark rhombus pattern on both sides of the blade, there are decorations of blue crystals and turquoise
The grip of the sword is bound by silk
The Sword of Goujian was unearthed in a lacquered wooden scabbard

Large bronze urn-shaped seismometer about six feet in diameter
Source: The Evolution of Progress: The Han Dynasty Seismograph

Content: Eight intricately designed dragon heads arranged symmetrically around the urn
Source: The Evolution of Progress: The Han Dynasty Seismograph

Content: Each dragon facing a different cardinal direction: N, NE, E, SE, S, SW, W, NW
Source: The Evolution of Progress: The Han Dynasty Seismograph

Content: Beneath each dragon head is a toad with its mouth open, facing inwards.
Source: The Evolution of Progress: The Han Dynasty Seismograph

Content: Central pendulum or weighted metal ball mechanism inside the urn
Source: The Evolution of Progress: The Han Dynasty Seismograph

Content: When triggered, a dragon releases a metal ball into the mouth of a toad
Source: The Evolution of Progress: The Han Dynasty Seismograph

Content: Ball-dropping action indicating the direction of an earthquakeâs origin
Source: The Evolution of Progress: The Han Dynasty Seismograph

The ancient southern-pointing chariot was a two-wheeled carriage, pulled by two horses attached to a single pole.
Source: South Pointing Chariot - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Content: The carriage itself was enclosed, with a two-tiered roof.
Source: South Pointing Chariot - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Content: A wooden statue of a mythical figure, with outstretched arms pointing south, was mounted on the roof.
Source: South Pointing Chariot - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Content: Inside the carriage was a complex system of gears and wheels.
Source: South Pointing Chariot - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Content: Two large wheels supported the carriage on either side.
Source: South Pointing Chariot - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Content: There were also several smaller vertical and horizontal gears (9 wheels in total, 120 teeth).
Source: South Pointing Chariot - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Content: A larger horizontal gear (48 teeth) was located in the center, connected to a vertical shaft.
Source: South Pointing Chariot - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Content: This vertical shaft, about the height of a person, supported the statue on the roof.
Source: South Pointing Chariot - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Content: This ingenious mechanical device ensured that the statue always pointed south, regardless of the chariot's movement.
Source: South Pointing Chariot - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Content: The horses were harnessed to the front of the chariot to pull it forward.
Source: South Pointing Chariot - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Content: south-pointing chariot

The zun is in the shape of a rhinoceros, dating from the Western Han dynasty.
The rhinoceros is shown as a powerful standing figure with a raised head.
The rhinoceros has pricked ears.
The rhinoceros has sharp tusks.
The eyes of the rhinoceros are made of bright black glass beads.
The back of the rhinoceros has a lid, hinged at the front.
The body of the rhinoceros is decorated with cloud motifs.
The cloud motifs are interspersed with spiral patterns.
The cloud and spiral patterns are inlaid with gold and silver.
The inlaid decoration suggests the fine hairs of the rhinoceros.
The bronze surface shows a mottled green patina, with turquoise and dark green tones, reflecting age and burial.
A zun in the shape of a rhinoceros, dating from the Western Han dynasty

The Water-powered Astronomical Clock Tower invented by Su Song is a tall, pagoda-like multi-story wooden tower.
The Water-powered Astronomical Clock Tower invented by Su Song contains mechanical devices inside.
An armillary sphere sat on the open top platform (roof level) and was rotated by the towerâs mechanism.
The upper structure had railings around the top platform beneath the roof canopy sheltering the armillary sphere (seen on reconstructions/models).
Source: Astronomical Clock of Su Song (1020-1101) | cabinet

Content: A reconstruction diagram of the Water-powered Astronomical Clock Tower invented by Su Song.
Hero's steam engine has an overall shape of a hollow sphere that rotates when steam is supplied.
Source: Aeolipile | Steam Turbine, Invention & Usage | Britannica

Content: The sphere of Hero's steam engine is typically fitted with oppositely bent tubes; the steam escaping from these tubes generates reactive torque, causing the sphere to rotate.
Source: Aeolipile | Steam Turbine, Invention & Usage | Britannica

Content: The classic material for the sphere of Hero's steam engine is brass.
Hero's steam engine employs a boiler and stand arrangement: a fire is lit beneath the water vessel, which is covered with a lid, generating steam that flows into the sphere.
Source: THE PNEUMATICS OF HERO OF ALEXANDRIA

Content: Hero's steam engine
The eyes of the bronze mask with protruding pupils extend outward in the form of tubular "pupils."
The mask displays broad, outstretched ears.
The bronze mask with protruding eyes features square perforations on the forehead and at the sides/temples (in some examples, extending along the ear panels).
Source: Exhibition replicates Sanxingdui sacrifice scene_Whatâs On-Shenzhen Government Online

Content: The bronze mask with protruding eyes has a narrow mouth, slightly upturned at the corners, revealing a subtle "smile."
Bronze mask with protruding eyes
The bronze sacred tree consists of three parts: the base, the tree, and a dragon beside the trunk.
The bronze sacred tree features a domed base with three arched, triangular openwork panels, forming the imagery of âthree sacred mountains.â
The trunk rises in three tiers, three branches per tier (nine branches in total).
The dragon on the bronze sacred tree descends along one side of the trunk.
Source: Bronze sacred trees at Sanxingdui Museum - CGTN

Content: the bronze sacred tree.
The overall shape of the Jade Zhang featuring a mountain worship scene is that of a knife-shaped jade artifact.
The Jade Zhang featuring a mountain worship scene has figures carved on it.
The Jade Zhang featuring a mountain worship scene has mountains carved on it.
The Jade Zhang featuring a mountain worship scene has cloud patterns carved between the figures and the mountains.
The Jade Zhang with mountain worship scene and the patterns carved upon it.
The overall design of the Sanxingdui bronze solar-shaped artifact features five radiating "spokes" connecting the center to the rim.
The Sanxingdui bronze solar-shaped artifact has a centrally protruding circular hub.
The Sanxingdui bronze solar-shaped artifact features a central circular hole and five evenly distributed small round holes along its outer rim.
The Sanxingdui bronze solar-shaped artifact has a diameter of approximately 85 centimeters.
The Sanxingdui bronze solar-shaped artifact
